title: Nigeria: Govt Moves to Increase Vat to 10 Percent
text:
Nigeria: Police Orders Shoot-At-Sight On Cultists, Ritualists in Ogun 
Ogungbesan hinted that of about 450, 000 corporate entities in the country, only about 125,000 pay taxes to government coffers. 
According to him, one of the greatest challenge facing the FIRS is that most companies that evade taxes are briefcase concerns that cannot be traced. 
He explained that the FIRS resorted to engagement to get tax defaulters to change their minds by paying their taxes as at when due. 
The FIRS boss said the agency tried different options in the past to enforce compliance, including the option of sealing companies that evade taxes, but discovered that it adversely affected man hour, the Gross Domestic Product and the economy as a whole. 
He maintained that he will continue with the option of engagement rather than clamp down on defaulters, pointing out that the former is already yielding results. 
He however declared that the FIRS will clam down on those who remained recalcitrant and would not not comply with the law. 
He said the desire of the FIRS is to achieve set revenue targets, pointing out that it will help shore up the economy. 
He said: "If we achieve our revenue targets, to a large extent government deficits will be reduced," "Our plan is to bring every business into the tax net, this economy can survive outside oil." 
Ogungbesan said the FIRS is doing everything possible to encourage payment of taxes, including allowing companies to pay in six installments and more. "I am ready to allow companies that are willing to pay up to 20 installments," he declared. Nigeria
